instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2915: What is 820-2915? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.PCH_INTRUDER_L: What is PCH_INTRUDER_L? PCH_INTRUDER_L is a signal that tells the machine the case has been opened by an intruder when it is low, the _L means it is present when it is low. This signal should always be high in a Macbook since it doesn’t use intrusion detection. .
definitions.RTC_RESET_L: What is RTC_RESET_L? RTC_RESET_L is a reset signal that is present when the signal is low, the _L means it is asserted when the voltage is low. The RESET signal will keep the PCH from turning on or booting up the machine. .
definitions.PCH_SRTCRST_L: What is PCH_SRTCRST_L? PCH_SRTCRST_L is a reset signal present for the RTC circuit that asserts when it is low in voltage, that is what _L means..
definitions.SMC_BATLOW_L: What is SMC_BATLOW_L? SMC_BATLOW_L refers to a power management signal that indicates a low battery condition. The "_L" suffix suggests that this is an active-low signal, meaning that it becomes low when the battery reaches a low voltage threshold..
definitions.PCH_INTVRMEN_L: What is PCH_INTVRMEN_L? PCH_INTVRMEN_L is a signal that stands for Internal Voltage Regulator Enable. When pulled high, this signal enables the internal 1.05 V regulators for the Suspend well in the PCH. This signal must be pulled-up to PPVRTC_G3H..
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> B Slow charging + doesn't start without battery
threads.message:
Hi Team:

Costumer reported slow charging; but on my side I've noticed that the board doesn't turn ON without the battery
And if the battery is plugged it first do like an attempt to start with fan spin then stop then start for real.
Test done with Official 85W charger

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>: 12.56V
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>: 3.470v
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>: 3.335V
S5:
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>: 5.019V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>: 3.335V
S4:
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL>: 3.335V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>: 0V

<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL>: 3.334V
<SIGNAL>SMC_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>:0V
<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL>:3.450V

RTC:
<SIGNAL>SYSCLK_CLK32K_RTC</SIGNAL>: 32khz ok with 0.428V amplitude
<SIGNAL>RTC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>: 3.329V
<SIGNAL>PCH_SRTCRST_L</SIGNAL>: 3.329V
<SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL>: 3.035V
<SIGNAL>PCH_INTVRMEN_L</SIGNAL>: 3.225V

Y5010: 20Mhz OK

<RESISTOR>R5040</RESISTOR>:98.8Ohms and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> present OK on Pin 1

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> B Slow charging + doesn't start without battery
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>: 0V"
Are you sure?
Check why...

"<SIGNAL>SMC_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>:0V"
PCH will not start with this value.
This is usually caused by incorrect charger; try another known good 85W charger.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> B Slow charging + doesn't start without battery
threads.message:
You probably have <SIGNAL>SMC_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> present, but missing <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> doesn't allow it to pass through <TRANSISTOR>Q5040</TRANSISTOR>.

BTW, <RESISTOR>R5040</RESISTOR> must have 100K, not 100ohms.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> B Slow charging + doesn't start without battery
threads.message: Just warning you that if you fix this it will likely have a dead GPU afterwards...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> B Slow charging + doesn't start without battery
threads.message: How do you explain that the board is working with a battery and <SIGNAL>SMC_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> is present only with the battery. ....? No graphic issues. ... "so far"

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> B Slow charging + doesn't start without battery
threads.message:
Why don't you try to solve <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> issue???
Check <TRANSISTOR>Q7820</TRANSISTOR> area.

If GPU dies (not yet), you can still fix it on Intel graphics at the end...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> B Slow charging + doesn't start without battery
threads.message:
Ola 2Informaticos

[B]Why don't you try to solve <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> issue???[/B] :
This is exactly what I'm trying,  that's why I've reported higher that:
P[B]<SIGNAL>M_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL>: 3.334V
<SIGNAL>SMC_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>:0V[/B]
As at <CHIP>U7940</CHIP> we need both voltages to generate <SIGNAL>PM_SUS_EN</SIGNAL>, that's why I'm focused on [B]<SIGNAL>SMC_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>[/B].......
Am I wrong to think that way?
Knowing all that should I suspect the SMC?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> B Slow charging + doesn't start without battery
threads.message: I got confused, need to know <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> value...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> B Slow charging + doesn't start without battery
threads.message:
It's OK we're humains.....no hay nada......
What do you mean by <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> value????

<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> is 0V with only the charger connected
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> value is 0V with only the battery connected
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> is 3.328V with both connected: of course in that case the board starts....
Resistance to ground for that rail 2 MOhms
In diode mode with the red probe to gnd: 0.519V

Anything else?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> B Slow charging + doesn't start without battery
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>SMC_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> are separated by <TRANSISTOR>Q5040</TRANSISTOR>.
Both have 0V?

Did you try another 85W charger?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> B Slow charging + doesn't start without battery
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> B Slow charging + doesn't start without battery
threads.message: Does it start on SMC bypass, with charger only?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> B Slow charging + doesn't start without battery
threads.message:
Yes it is, except that it's doing the same like with the battery: fan spins then stops for 2-5sec then start again but doesn't stop  all that in full speed of course.....
are you thinking to something in particular? should I check all the sensors lines page 44?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> B Slow charging + doesn't start without battery
threads.message:
It starts in SMC bypass without battery connected?
Is normal that fans spin to max.
Connect both battery and charger, then run proper ASD.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> B Slow charging + doesn't start without battery
threads.message: OK thanks  I'll mount the proper asd and get back to you

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> B Slow charging + doesn't start without battery
threads.message:
Runned the proper ASD: [B]BAD BATTERY[/B] ( not official one......)

Can close the topic and mark it as SOLVED

Thanks
